node.title: It’s an Interactive Experience, Charlie Brown!
node.alt: A rendering of the Charlie Brown “Aaugh!” meter in the closet of his bedroom, in the interactive experience that is headed to the Ala Moana Center in Honolulu.
node.description: An adventure awaits visitors in Honolulu in “The Search for Snoopy,” starting in March.
node.content: ["\u201cPeanuts\u201d fans who have dreamed of visiting Snoopy\u2019s red doghouse, Lucy\u2019s therapy booth (only 5 cents!) or Charlie Brown\u2019s classroom will have their chance next year, with an interactive experience in Honolulu called \u201cThe Search for Snoopy: A Peanuts Adventure.\u201d", "The event will take visitors through the familiar scenery of Charles M. Schulz\u2019s newspaper strips and cartoons, and will be presented at Ala Moana Center, an open-air mall, starting in March.", "\u201cThe beauty of \u2018Peanuts\u2019 is that there are 17,500-and-some-odd strips that Sparky \u2014 Charles Schulz \u2014 created over the 50 years of \u2018Peanuts\u2019 in syndication,\u201d which provided many stories, themes and locations to mine, Craig Herman, a Peanuts Worldwide vice president, said in a conference call with the show\u2019s producer. (Original \u201cPeanuts\u201d strips were published from Oct. 2, 1965, through Feb. 13, 2000. The last original installment came out the day after Schulz\u2019s death.)", "For the Hawaii experience, Peanuts Worldwide partnered with Kilburn Live, the company that produced an interactive Dr. Seuss Experience, in a collaboration that began three years ago. \u201cIt takes a long time to get it right,\u201d Mark Manuel, the chief executive of Kilburn, said in the interview.", "Other set pieces in \u201cThe Search for Snoopy\u201d include Charlie Brown\u2019s bedroom, where visitors can release a Charlie Brown-like \u201cAaugh!\u201d that will be measured and ranked, and Charlie Brown\u2019s classroom, where participants can hear themselves in the indecipherable garble of the adults as they were heard in \u201cPeanuts\u201d on TV. A national tour of the show is planned following its run in Honolulu."]
